intro: Sphaeralcea coccinea subsp. elata, commonly known as the desert four o'clock, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its showy, bright orange to red flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid environments. Its leaves are narrow and gray-green, often covered in fine hairs to reduce water loss. The species is part of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is known for its ecological importance to pollinators.
